prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: OH between 650 and 685 GHz (north)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Three suitable objects within 10 degrees of each other in this frequency range: J125652.5+275902, J132859.3+292327, and J133542.7+300403. The object are in the H-ATLAS NGP (north) field. The continuum intensities have been acquired by interpolating SPIRE photometry from the H-ATLAS program. The peak (absorption) intensity is estimated to be 30% of the continuum.
The purpose of this science goal is to look for signs of OH absorption (rest frequency 2.5 THz) at high redshifts and also acquire a continuum baseline to compare any potential OH absorption with.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The observations have been split into separate science goals because the redshifted spectral features cannot be covered using the same spectral scan settings for all targets. The four band 9 science goals are similar except for the frequency tunings.
The sources were selected from the HATLAS survey. There are 30 objects with known spectroscopic redshift in the survey and 15 of those have redshift >2.6, a requirement so that the OH 119.233um doublet falls in the ALMA bands. Of those 15, we excluded those where the OH double falls in the gap between bands (4 sources). From the remaining sources we selected those which will maximize the number of sources and still abide to the 10 degree requirement, which leaves out total sample to 8.
Imaging requirements: At redshifts of >2.6 all the targets have sizes <0.5” and can be considered point sources for a compact array configuration. All the objects have optical counterparts. Coordinates are accurate to 1” and taken from the HATLAS catalogue, which is very close in wavelength to the redshifted position of the OH 120um doublet in our sources (430-620um). We note these 3 objects are in the North field (+25 degrees), but well within the observational capabilities of ALMA.
Sensitivity: To estimate the sensitivity we interpolated the flux of the continuum at the position of the redshifted OH doublet 119.233um for each source using the Herschel/SPIRE 250, 350, and 500um fluxes (see Table 1 in proposal). We note that for the 3 objects in the sample with a redshifted doublet >500um we extrapolated linearly the 350-500um (in log space) which should be close to a Rayleigh-Jeans tail. The estimated continuum flux densities for the targets in this science goal are 275.4, 151.2,and 149.3 mJy per beam respectively (Table 1). Using the HERUS program as benchmark we see that the absorption features are about 20-40% of the continuum flux, so we use 30% as a conservative average (82.62, 45.36, and 44.79 mJy). We wish to achieve a minimum S/N of 15 in order to be able to tell the continuum emission from any potential OH absorption features in the spectra. These results in a sensitivity of 5 mJY and we will obtain a S/N in the continuum(line) of 55(17), 30(9), and 30(9) (see Table 1 in proposal). Spectral resolution is not a priority and thus we can acquire the desired S/N ratio by smoothing the spectra into resolution elements with a width of 1.875 GHz (the bandwidth of a single spectral window).
Correlator setup: Assuming the OH absorption features have a FWHM of 1000 km/s, the full extent of the redshifted absorption features will be spread out over a frequency range of approximately 2 GHz in all cases. The single spectral line mode in ALMA band 9 is not capable of fitting both the absorption feature and a featureless comparison continuum spectrum into a single observation. Furthermore the different sources exhibit different redshifts and thus show the OH absorption feature at different parts of band 9. A spectral scan allows us to observe multiple objects simultaneously with the same setup while also acquiring sufficient continuum baseline in addition to the potential OH absorption feature in all cases. The minimum and maximum frequencies of the scan range have been selected to encompass the redshifted OH absorption feature (rest frequency ~2.5 THz; sky frequencies 661.7, 659.3, and 678.4 GHz) in all objects which we expect to potentially show it in as large a frequency range as possible. Spectral resolution is not a priority for this study and thus we make use of the widest possible scan mode.
Including calibration and observing this specific science goal requires 2.18 hours of observing time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: OH in band 8 (gama)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
There is a single suitable object (J142413.9+022303) in this science goal, which is observable at ALMA band 8. The object is in the H-ATLAS GAMA field. The continuum intensities have been acquired by interpolating Herschel/SPIRE photometry from the H-ATLAS program. The peak (absorption) intensity is estimated to be 30% of the continuum.
Unlike the other three science goals, this one makes use of the "spectral line" mode instead of spectral scanning. It centers the OH absorption position in the upper sideband and compare it to continuum emission in the lower sideband.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The observations have been split into separate science goals because the redshifted spectral features cannot be covered using the same spectral scan settings for all targets. The four band 9 science goals are similar except for the frequency tunings. In The remaining scan, this one, the doublet falls in Band 8.
The sources were selected from the HATLAS survey. There are 30 objects with known spectroscopic redshift in the survey and 15 of those have redshift >2.6, a requirement so that the OH119.233um doublet falls in the ALMA bands. Of those 15, we excluded those where the OH double falls in the gap between bands (4 sources). From the remaining sources we selected those which will maximize the number of sources and still abide to the 10 degree requirement, which leaves out total sample to 8. This targe is the highest-z object making a crucial target in our sample. Because of the higher sensitivity of Band 8 it also requires less time.
Imaging requirements: At a redshifts of 4.2 this targets have a size <0.5” and can be considered point sources for a compact array configuration. Coordinates are accurate to 1” and taken from the HATLAS catalogue.
Sensitivity: As with the other science goals in Band 9, we strive for a S/N ratio of at least 15 in order to adequately claim detection of any OH absorption if it is present. However the observing time estimate for this case is dominated by calibration observations and overheads. Increasing sensitivity from 10 mJy to 1 mJy results in less than two minutes of extra integration time and thus it is prudent to spend those two minutes for achieving a much higher S/N ratio than with the other sources. This is because the predicted flux is less accurate as we have to extrapolate its flux from the Herschel/SPIRE 500um flux. We expect the continuum emission of this source to be approximately 214 mJy (within a factor 1.5) and thus the sensitivity we desire would result in S/N of about 200. Using the HERUS program as benchmark we see that the absorption features are about 20-40% of the continuum flux, so we use 30% as a conservative average (59.37 mJy), which we can measure with a S/N of 59 (Table 1).
Correlator setup: Unlike with the other four science goals, it is more time efficient to use the single spectrum mode instead of performing a spectral scan. We have placed the upper sideband slightly on the blue side of the expected sky frequency (476.8 GHz) of the OH absorption, as we expect the bulk of any absorption to happen in the blueshifted outflow region. The lower sideband is suitably separated from the expected OH absorption and thus we observe it for getting a continuum spectrum for comparing with the OH absorption in the upper sideband. In this case as well, we are not interested in spectral resolution and thus favour high S/N over high spectral resolution.
Including calibration and observing this specific science goal requires 29.53 minutes of observing time.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Why do ultraluminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs) at z>1 look like scaled-up spiral discs? Why were these ULIRGs such a major contributor to the star formation density at that epoch, yet they contribute less than a percent today? A likely driver may be changes in AGN feedback. Herschel observations of hydroxyl (OH) have proven extremely efficient in characterising AGN-driven outflows in the local Universe, and showing that they are relatively common. These outflows provide the only direct evidence that fuel for star formation is being removed. Are these outflows also common at high-z? Are they powered by the same mechanism? We propose a landmark study of AGN-driven outflows in 8 ULIRGs at redshifts 2.6−4.2, with the best available outflow diagnostic, OH, and the best available sample of gravitationally lensed sub-mm galaxies, using the flux amplification to maximise ALMA’s sensitivity to this key diagnostic. These observations will present an unprecedented description of AGN feedback in the early Universe. Even non-detections of OH would guarantee a high-profile result as they would indicate a major change in AGN feedback mechanisms during the Universe’s peak metal production epoch.
